title: NASA will announce update to Mars sample return plans on Jan. 7. Here's how to listen in - Space.com
summary:
NASA Prepares to Announce Updates on Mars Sample Return Mission

Date: January 7, 2025

Source: Space.com

NASA is set to hold an audio-only press conference to update the public about its Mars sample return mission, focused on the challenges and strategies to return samples from Mars to Earth.

  • The press conference will start at 1:00 p.m. EST and can be listened to via NASA's website.
  • NASA Administrator Bill Nelson will lead the briefing, discussing efforts to manage costs and risks associated with the mission.
  • The Mars Sample Return program aims to bring Mars samples to Earth to advance scientific understanding of the planet.
  • The current plan to return samples is facing significant cost increases, estimated at up to $11 billion.
  • New strategies being explored may involve collaborations with industry to streamline operations.
"The bottom line is that $11 billion is too expensive, and not returning samples until 2040 is unacceptably too long," said Bill Nelson.

This upcoming briefing is essential as NASA seeks to rejuvenate its Mars exploration goals and compete with other nations planning similar missions.
newTitle: NASA Prepares to Announce Updates on Mars Sample Return Mission

VIAVI Delivers Precision Components for NASA’s Europa Clipper Mission - TimesTech
summary:
VIAVI Delivers Precision Components for NASA’s Europa Clipper Mission

Publication Date: January 7, 2025 | Source: Times Tech

VIAVI Solutions has announced its contribution to NASA’s Europa Clipper mission, providing a precision order sorting filter essential for the spacecraft's mapping imaging spectrometer, MISE, which will analyze Europa's surface composition and potential habitability.

  • VIAVI supplied a precision order sorting filter for the MISE instrument.
  • MISE is vital for analyzing Europa's surface and determining the habitability of its subsurface ocean.
  • The filter combines several key technologies to meet the mission's stringent requirements.
  • The Europa Clipper mission launched on October 14, 2024, and will orbit Jupiter by April 2030.
  • MISE will conduct 49 flybys of Europa to gather data on its potential to support life.
“We are honored to support NASA’s mission to explore one of the most intriguing moons in our solar system,” said Luke Scrivanich, Senior Vice President and General Manager, Optical Security and Performance, VIAVI.

This collaboration highlights the important role of precision engineering in space exploration as the Europa Clipper mission aims to unlock the mysteries of Europa and its potential for life.
newTitle: VIAVI Provides Precision Components for NASA's Europa Clipper Mission

title: NASA’s Mission to Understand the Sun with the Parker Solar Probe - AZoSensors
summary:
NASA’s Mission to Understand the Sun with the Parker Solar Probe

Date: December 25, 2023 | Source: NASA

Introduction: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe has achieved a historic milestone by surviving its closest approach to the Sun, at just 3.8 million miles from its surface, on Christmas Eve. This mission aims to uncover the secrets of the Sun's behavior and its influence on the solar system.

  • The Parker Solar Probe braved intense heat and radiation to gather crucial data about the Sun’s outer atmosphere known as the corona.
  • This mission has three primary objectives: to understand what heats the corona, trace the origins of the solar wind, and comprehend the acceleration of solar particles.
  • The probe travels at speeds of up to 430,000 miles per hour, making it the fastest human-made object to date.
  • Initial findings indicate a complex structure of the Sun’s corona, consisting of jagged spikes and valleys.
  • The Parker Solar Probe's research may help predict and prepare for solar events that affect space weather.
“If we imagine the Earth-Sun distance as the length of a football field, the probe would be only four yards from the end zone.”

Conclusion: The Parker Solar Probe not only represents a significant advancement in solar exploration but also has the potential to reshape our understanding of stellar environments and their impact on habitable conditions beyond Earth.
newTitle: NASA’s Mission to Understand the Sun with the Parker Solar Probe

title: Video captured from Space Station shows Earth bathed in intense green aurora - India Today
summary:
Video Captured from Space Station Shows Earth Bathed in Intense Green Aurora

Published On: Jan 7, 2025 | Source: India Today

Nasa astronaut Don Pettit has captivated audiences worldwide with a stunning video showcasing the vibrant green auroras from the International Space Station (ISS).

  • The video highlights the breathtaking natural light display caused by charged particles from the Sun interacting with Earth’s magnetic field.
  • It emphasizes the beauty of this celestial spectacle as seen from space.
  • The video offers a rare glimpse of the auroras typically visible in high-latitude regions.
  • Pettit’s post was captioned “Flying over aurora; intensely green,” drawing admiration on social media.
  • The ISS orbits approximately 400 kilometers above Earth, providing unique documentation opportunities.
“Flying over aurora; intensely green.” - Don Pettit

This captivating video further showcases the incredible sights that can be witnessed beyond our atmosphere, illustrating the complexity of solar activity's impact on Earth's environment.
newTitle: Video Captured from Space Station Shows Earth Bathed in Intense Green Aurora

title: High Harmonic Generation Guides Titanium Development - AZoM
summary:
High Harmonic Generation Guides Titanium Development

Date: October 2023

Source: Communications Physics

Researchers from Yokohama National University have developed a method to study how titanium's electron orientation and behavior influence its physical properties. Their findings could contribute to the development of more advanced and efficient titanium alloys.

  • The study focuses on the use of high harmonic generation to investigate titanium's atomic and electronic structure.
  • Titanium is highly valued for its resistance to chemical corrosion and exceptional strength-to-weight ratio.
  • The method allows researchers to observe how titanium's electronic structure behaves under laser exposure.
  • Titanium's unique uniaxial structure influences its mechanical properties and reactions to applied forces.
  • The findings could lead to the design of stronger titanium alloys for various industries, including aerospace and medicine.

“By mapping how these bonds change with direction, we can understand why titanium has such unique mechanical properties.”
— Dr. Tetsuya Matsunaga, Study Lead Author, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency

This research highlights the complexity of titanium's electron movement and provides insights necessary for enhancing its applications in advanced manufacturing.
newTitle: High Harmonic Generation Guides Titanium Development

title: The Atoms in Your Body Once Traveled Beyond the Galaxy—Here’s How They Returned - Indian Defence Review
summary:
The Atoms in Your Body Once Traveled Beyond the Galaxy—Here’s How They Returned

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: The Astrophysical Journal Letters

New research reveals how atoms forged in stars leave their galaxies, travel through space, and contribute to the formation of new stars, planets, and life, challenging traditional views of galactic boundaries.

  • Elements heavier than hydrogen and helium originate primarily in stars through supernovae and neutron star mergers.
  • Stars expel heavy elements into the circumgalactic medium (CGM), which acts as a recycling system over billions of years.
  • The Hubble Space Telescope's analysis showed heavy elements like carbon are present far beyond galaxies, indicating ongoing material cycles.
  • Differences between star-forming and passive galaxies reveal how stellar activity affects the abundance of elements in the CGM.
“The same carbon in our bodies most likely spent a significant amount of time outside of the galaxy!” - Jessica Werk

These findings deepen our understanding of cosmic processes that shape galaxies and the essential materials for life.
newTitle: How Atoms Journey Across the Universe to Fuel Life

title: Four asteroids to hit Earth? NASA tracks huge space rocks moving at high speed; check details - Moneycontrol
summary:
NASA Tracks Four Asteroids Set to Safely Pass Earth

Date: January 07, 2025 / Source: Moneycontrol

NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) is monitoring four asteroids that will pass Earth safely on January 8 and 9, 2025, which provides opportunities for scientific research.

  • Asteroid 2024 YA10: Approximate size of 67 feet, closest approach at 2,110,000 miles on January 8, 2025.
  • Asteroid 2024 BM1: Approximately 69 feet wide, closest approach at 2,740,000 miles on January 8, 2025.
  • Asteroid 2024 PT5: Measures 36 feet, closest approach at 1,120,000 miles on January 9, 2025.
  • Asteroid 2024 YD13: Approximately 75 feet wide, closest approach at 3,480,000 miles on January 9, 2025.
“NASA’s JPL continues to monitor these asteroids. Although none pose a threat, their proximity provides an excellent opportunity for scientific observation and research.”

This event highlights the importance of ongoing space monitoring and understanding celestial objects.
newTitle: NASA Tracks Four Asteroids Set to Safely Pass Earth

title: Stephen Hawking Birth Anniversary: Know All About The Legendary Scientist - Free Press Journal
summary:
Stephen Hawking Birth Anniversary: Know All About The Legendary Scientist

Publication Date: Tuesday, January 07, 2025

Stephen Hawking, a renowned physicist and author, dedicated his life to understanding the universe. He made significant contributions to cosmology despite battling a debilitating illness.

Key Points:

  • Born on January 8, 1942, Hawking was a cosmologist, theoretical physicist, and author.
  • He made groundbreaking contributions to our understanding of black holes and singularities.
  • Diagnosed with ALS, he transcended his disability to continue his scientific work.
  • Hawking's theory of singularity reshaped concepts of the universe, linking black holes to the Big Bang theory.
“The greatest enemy of knowledge is not ignorance, it is the illusion of knowledge.” - Stephen Hawking

Stephen Hawking's legacy continues to inspire future generations in the fields of physics and cosmology.
newTitle: Celebrating Stephen Hawking: Legacy of a Legendary Scientist

title: Hubble rings in new year by capturing perfect gravitational lens - News9 LIVE
summary:
The Hubble Space Telescope has captured a busy patch of sky in the constellation of Hydra.

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

The Hubble Space Telescope has ushered in the new year by capturing a nearly perfect gravitational lens. A smooth golden galaxy is nearly surrounded by a complete ring, occurring due to a rare alignment of two galaxies along the same line of sight from Earth.

  • Background galaxy dates back to when the universe was only 2.5 billion years old.
  • Foreground galaxy bends and distorts the light from the distant background galaxy.
  • Gravitational lenses allow astronomers to study early universe processes.
  • Observation targeted a spiral galaxy designated as LEDA 803211, located 622 million light-years away.
"Such gravitational lenses were predicted by Albert Einstein, but he never expected that telescopes would ever get powerful enough to actually resolve them."

This discovery highlights the capabilities of modern telescopes to probe the distant universe and unveil secrets from the dawn of time.
newTitle: Hubble Rings in New Year by Capturing Perfect Gravitational Lens

title: Jurassic journey: Massive 166M-year-old dinosaur footprints discovered in UK - Türkiye Today
summary:
Jurassic journey: Massive 166M-year-old dinosaur footprints discovered in UK

Publication Date: Not Provided | Source: Türkiye Today

A remarkable discovery has been made in a quarry in Oxfordshire, unveiling the U.K.’s largest dinosaur trackway site. Around 200 giant footprints, dating back 166 million years, cover the limestone floor, providing insight into the movements of two distinct types of dinosaurs.

  • The trackways were made by the long-necked Cetiosaurus and the smaller Megalosaurus.
  • The longest trackway measures 150 meters, with only part of the quarry excavated.
  • Over 100 scientists and volunteers participated in the excavation this summer.
  • The footprints offer a glimpse into the interaction between different dinosaur species.
“This is one of the most impressive track sites I’ve ever seen, both in terms of scale and the size of the tracks,” - Professor Kirsty Edgar

Scientists are working to preserve the site, hoping further excavation will reveal more about prehistoric life.
newTitle: Discovery of the UK’s Largest Dinosaur Footprint Site Revealed

title: Astronomers resolve individual stars halfway across universe thanks to ‘Dragon Arc’ - News9 LIVE
summary:
Astronomers resolve individual stars halfway across universe thanks to ‘Dragon Arc’

Date: New Delhi
Source: Science News

Astronomers have successfully resolved 44 individual stars from a galaxy located 6.5 billion lightyears away, utilizing the advanced capabilities of the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) and observing a distorted galaxy called the ‘Dragon Arc’.

  • The Dragon Arc galaxy is distorted due to gravitational lensing caused by a massive cluster of galaxies, 4 billion lightyears away.
  • This achievement sets a new record for the highest number of individual stars detected in the distant universe.
  • The study allows for better examination of dark matter, a mysterious substance that interacts with matter only through gravity.
  • The researchers found that most stars in the Dragon Arc were red supergiants, analogous to Betelgeuse in Orion.
“This groundbreaking discovery demonstrates, for the first time, that studying large numbers of individual stars in a distant galaxy is possible.” - Fengwu Sun

This discovery could reshape our understanding of star formation and dark matter in the universe.
newTitle: Astronomers Spot Individual Stars 6.5 Billion Lightyears Away Thanks to ‘Dragon Arc’

6 Mesmerising Space Pictures From NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
summary:
6 Mesmerising Space Pictures From NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Date: Jan 7, 2025 | Source: Times Now

This article showcases six stunning images captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, featuring breathtaking celestial phenomena and details about the objects.

  • The Mice NGC 4676: Two colliding spiral galaxies, merging into one giant galaxy.
  • A Spiral Star Factory: The spiral galaxy NGC 5668 located in Virgo.
  • Westerlund 2: A massive group of stars situated 20,000 light-years away.
  • Mystic Mountain: A gas and dust pillar analyzed by Hubble.
  • The Little Dumbbell Nebula: A beautiful nebula located 3400 light-years away.
  • MACS JO416.1-2403: A galaxy cluster revealing images from the early universe.
“This image taken by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope showcases the galaxy cluster MACS J0416.1–2403, one of six under study in the Hubble Frontier Fields program.”

These images not only highlight the incredible capabilities of the Hubble Space Telescope but also provide insights into the vastness and beauty of our universe.
newTitle: 6 Mesmerising Space Pictures From NASA Hubble Space Telescope

title: 12 Pieces Of ‘Good News’ From 2024 For Those Who Are Fed Up With The Bad Ones - Bored Panda
summary:
12 Inspiring Stories From 2024 That May Bring You More Optimism

Publication Date: Source:

The internet is abundant with negativity that we often overlook uplifting news pieces. This article highlights positive events from 2024 that mainstream media failed to cover, reminding us that not everything is grim.

  • Kenya's black rhinos doubled in number to 1,000.
  • Researchers discovered superworms that can digest plastic in Singapore.
  • Two teenagers invented a microplastic-filtering device and won $50,000.
  • Seven countries generate over 99% of their electricity from renewable sources.
  • 20 indigenous groups in the Peruvian Amazon secured land rights to over 75,000 acres.
  • Japanese researchers developed a biodegradable plastic that dissolves in seawater.
  • The largest dam removal in U.S. history was completed, benefiting salmon and local communities.
  • Pakistan tripled their mangrove forests over the last 30 years.
  • Uruguay ran on 100% renewable energy for 10 months straight.
  • India electrified over 94% of its railways in five years.
  • Greece and Sweden announced bans on bottom trawling to protect oceans.
  • Scientists discovered almost 100 new deep-sea species living 14,000 feet under the sea.
“In the long term, these sites may be better suited by providing more of a mix of positive info,” said researcher Carey Morewedge.

This collection of stories serves as a reminder that positive change is happening worldwide, and we should seek out and celebrate these developments.
newTitle: 12 Inspiring Stories From 2024 That May Bring You More Optimism

title: 2024 Tech Roundup: Breakthroughs shaping future - CGTN
Earth's Rotation Day 2025 Date: Know The Significance of the Day That Honours Léon Foucault's Experiment - LatestLY
summary:
Earth's Rotation Day 2025: Know The Significance of the Day That Honours Léon Foucault's Experiment

Date: January 8, 2025 | Source: LatestLY

Introduction

Earth's Rotation Day is celebrated annually on January 8 to commemorate Léon Foucault's groundbreaking pendulum experiment that visually demonstrated Earth's rotation.

Earth's Rotation Day 2025 Date

Earth's Rotation Day 2025 will be observed on Wednesday, January 8.

Key Points

  • Earth's Rotation Day honors Léon Foucault's contribution to science.
  • Foucault's Pendulum provided direct proof of Earth's rotation around its axis.
  • The experiment was first demonstrated in 1851 at the Panthéon in Paris.
  • The day serves as an opportunity for education on Earth's rotation, the Coriolis effect, and more.
  • Earth's rotation slightly slows over time due to tidal effects from the Moon.

Notable Quotes or Statistics

Foucault's experiment provided the first direct, visual proof that the Earth rotates around its axis.

Conclusion

Earth's Rotation Day not only commemorates a pivotal moment in scientific history but also encourages ongoing discussions and education about fundamental astronomical concepts.
newTitle: Earth's Rotation Day 2025: Honoring Léon Foucault's Scientific Contribution

title: Alert! NASA Warns Of 2 Giant Asteroids Set For Close Encounter With Earth On January 8: Time, Speed, And Dista - Times Now
summary:
NASA Warns of Two Asteroids Approaching Earth on January 8

Updated: January 7, 2025, 11:08 IST | Source: NASA

NASA has confirmed that two airplane-sized asteroids, named 2024 YA10 and 2024 BM1, are set to make close approaches to Earth tomorrow, January 8, 2025. While these celestial objects will come relatively close in astronomical terms, they pose no threat to our planet.

  • The first asteroid, 2024 YA10, is about 67 feet in diameter and traveling at 43,034 km/h, passing at a safe distance of 3,390,000 kilometers.
  • The second asteroid, 2024 BM1, measures 69 feet in diameter and will fly by at a distance of 4,410,000 kilometers, moving at 32,691 km/h.
  • Neither asteroid qualifies as a Potentially Hazardous Object (PHO) as they are smaller than 150 meters and remain well outside NASA's risk threshold.
  • NASA employs ground-based and space-based telescopes to monitor Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) effectively.
NASA categorizes an asteroid as a PHO only if it exceeds 150 meters in diameter and approaches within 7.5 million kilometers of Earth.

While these asteroids may sound alarming, they are safely passing by, and NASA continues to keep a close watch on such celestial objects.
newTitle: NASA Warns of Two Asteroids Approaching Earth on January 8

title: Green Breakthrough: Scientists Convert CO2 into Acetaldehyde - ChemAnalyst
summary:
Green Breakthrough: Scientists Convert CO2 into Acetaldehyde

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Nature Synthesis

This article discusses a significant advancement in chemical production, where researchers have developed a novel copper-based catalyst that efficiently converts carbon dioxide (CO2) into acetaldehyde with high selectivity, presenting a sustainable alternative to traditional methods.

  • Acetaldehyde is traditionally produced using the Wacker process, relying on petrochemical sources.
  • The new catalyst achieves 92% selectivity for acetaldehyde, greatly improving on previous methods.
  • This breakthrough could potentially replace the energy-intensive Wacker process, reducing CO2 emissions significantly.
  • Researchers utilized spark ablation to create tiny copper clusters for the process.
“The Wacker process has remained largely unchanged for over 60 years, so the time was ripe for a green breakthrough,” says Koolen.

This development is poised to impact various industries, from pharmaceuticals to agriculture, offering a more sustainable approach to chemical manufacturing.
newTitle: Green Breakthrough: Scientists Convert CO2 into Acetaldehyde

title: Surprise Turning of Ancient 'Wheel of Ghosts' Casts Doubt on Astronomical Purpose - ScienceAlert
summary:
Surprise Turning of Ancient 'Wheel of Ghosts' Casts Doubt on Astronomical Purpose

Publication Date: 2024
Source: Remote Sensing

The Rujm el-Hiri site, also known as the 'Wheel of Ghosts', has been widely recognized as an ancient astronomical observatory. However, recent research suggests it has undergone significant shifts in position over thousands of years, raising questions about its original purpose.

  • The ancient site, located in the Golan Heights, was previously believed to align with celestial bodies.
  • A new study indicates that the structure has rotated and shifted over time, No longer aligning with the night sky as initially thought.
  • The research combined geomagnetic analysis, tectonic reconstruction, and remote sensing techniques to understand the site's historical changes.
  • Initial construction of Rujm el-Hiri may date back to 4500 BCE, with modifications continuing until the Bronze Age.
  • The site consists of a central cairn and several concentric circles of basalt stone, measuring about 150 meters across.
"Rujm el-Hiri is a prime example of such a complex sequence."

This study highlights the need for further research in the region, potentially revealing more about similar ancient structures worldwide.
newTitle: Surprising Findings Challenge Purpose of Ancient 'Wheel of Ghosts'
